## Your Computational Toolkit

Here are the tools you'll use in this course:

| Tool | What It Is | Analogy |
|------|-----------|--------|
| **R** | The programming language for data analysis | Like English â€” the language you write in |
| **RStudio** | The software where you write R code | Like Microsoft Word â€” your writing interface |
| **Quarto** | Creates documents with code AND text | Like a Word doc that can run code |
| **Git** | Version control (tracks changes) | Like "Track Changes" in Word, but better |
| **GitHub** | Cloud storage for your Git projects | Like Google Drive, but for code |

::: {.callout-note}
R is the language, RStudio is the interface. You write R code *inside* RStudio.

**Want more on Git?** See [Why Learn Git?](why_teach_github.md) for the full explanation with examples.
:::

### Quarto: Your New Document Format

In this course, you won't use Word or Google Docs. Instead, you'll write **Quarto documents** (`.qmd` files) that contain:

- Your written analysis (in English)
- Your code (in R)
- The output of your code (plots, tables, results)

When you **Render** a Quarto document, everything combines into a beautifully formatted HTML or PDF file!

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## Also taking MA22015 (Statistics 2B)?

In MA22015, you use **R Markdown** (`.Rmd` files) instead of Quarto (`.qmd` files). Don't worry â€” they're very similar!

| Feature | R Markdown (`.Rmd`) | Quarto (`.qmd`) |
|---------|---------------------|-----------------|
| Used in | MA22015 | MA22019 (this course) |
| Button to run | **Knit** | **Render** |
| File header | Uses `output: html_document` | Uses `format: html` |
| Syntax | Nearly identical | Nearly identical |

Think of Quarto as the "next generation" of R Markdown â€” same idea, slightly updated syntax. Skills transfer directly between them!
:::

## A Quick Tour of RStudio

When you first open RStudio, you'll see **three panes**. The fourth pane (Source) appears when you open a file.

::: {.callout-tip}
**Where's the Source pane?** It only appears when you open a file (`.R`, `.qmd`, etc.). Go to **File â†’ Open File** or double-click a file in the Files pane to see it.
:::

![RStudio interface showing the four main panes: Source (top-left), Console (bottom-left), Environment (top-right), and Files/Plots/Help (bottom-right)](../img/rstudio_interface.png)

| Pane | Location | What It Does |
|------|----------|-------------|
| **Source** | Top-left | Where you write and edit code files (.R, .qmd) â€” *appears when you open a file* |
| **Console** | Bottom-left | Where you run code and see immediate output |
| **Environment** | Top-right | Shows your data and variables |
| **Files/Plots/Help** | Bottom-right | Browse files, view plots, get help |

> **Tip**: If a pane is missing, go to **View â†’ Panes â†’ Show All Panes**.

### The Most Important Buttons

| Button | Where | What It Does |
|--------|-------|-------------|
| **Run** | Source pane toolbar | Runs the current line of code |
| **Render** | Source pane toolbar | Converts your .qmd to HTML/PDF |
| **Pull** | Git pane (top-right) | Downloads updates from GitHub |
| **Push** | Git pane (top-right) | Uploads your work to GitHub |

![Git workflow: Clone for first download, Pull to get updates, Push to upload your work](../img/git_workflow.png)

## 2. Configure Git in RStudio

Git is the version control system that connects RStudio to GitHub. You need to set it up once.

### On University Lab Computers

1. Open **RStudio**
2. Go to **Tools â†’ Global Options â†’ Git/SVN**
3. Check that the **Git executable** box shows a path (e.g., `C:\Program Files\Git\bin\git.exe`)
   - If it's empty or says "Not Found", see the [Troubleshooting Guide](troubleshooting.qmd)
4. Click **OK**

### On Personal Computers (Windows)

If Git isn't already installed:

1. Download Git from [git-scm.com/download/win](https://git-scm.com/download/win)
2. Run the installer â€” accept all defaults
3. Open **RStudio**
4. Go to **Tools â†’ Global Options â†’ Git/SVN**
5. The Git executable should now show `C:\Program Files\Git\bin\git.exe`
6. Click **OK**

### On Personal Computers (Mac)

Git is usually pre-installed on Macs. To check:

1. Open **RStudio**
2. Go to **Tools â†’ Global Options â†’ Git/SVN**
3. Check if the Git executable shows `/usr/bin/git` or similar

If Git is not found:

1. Open **Terminal** (Applications â†’ Utilities â†’ Terminal)
2. Type `git --version` and press Enter
3. If prompted, click **Install** to install the Xcode Command Line Tools
4. Restart RStudio and check Git/SVN settings again

### Tell Git Who You Are

In the RStudio **Console**, run this once (replace with your details):

```r
install.packages("usethis")  # Only needed once
library(usethis)
use_git_config(user.name = "Your Name", user.email = "abc123@bath.ac.uk")
```

::: {.callout-warning}
## âš ï¸ Do NOT save your projects in cloud-synced folders!

Cloud sync services (OneDrive, iCloud, Dropbox, Google Drive) corrupt Git repositories. Git creates thousands of tiny files that these services try to sync, causing crashes and data loss.

**Check your setup:**

- **Windows**: If your Documents folder shows a cloud icon, it's synced to OneDrive. Create your folder at `C:\MA22019\` instead.
- **Mac**: Go to *System Settings â†’ Apple ID â†’ iCloud â†’ iCloud Drive â†’ Options*. If "Desktop & Documents Folders" is ON, create your folder at `~/MA22019/` (in your home folder, not Documents).
- **University PCs**: The H: Drive is safe â€” use that!
:::

## Understanding RStudio Projects

An **RStudio Project** is a folder with a special `.Rproj` file that tells RStudio "this is a project."

### Why Use Projects?

| Benefit | What It Means |
|---------|---------------|
| **Working directory** | R knows where your files are â€” no confusing file paths |
| **Everything together** | Data, code, and output all in one place |
| **Reproducible** | Your code works on any computer, not just yours |
| **Git integration** | The Git pane appears automatically |

### How to Open a Project

1. Navigate to the project folder in File Explorer/Finder
2. Double-click the `.Rproj` file
3. RStudio opens with that project loaded

> **Rule**: Always work inside a project! If you don't see a `.Rproj` file in your Files pane, you're probably not in a project.

## 4. Clone the Materials Repository

The `materials` repo contains all course content: case studies, labs, and solutions. You clone it once and pull updates weekly.

1. In RStudio: **File â†’ New Project â†’ Version Control â†’ Git**
2. **Repository URL**: `https://github.bath.ac.uk/ma22019-2026/materials.git`
3. **Create project as subdirectory of**: Browse to `MA22019/` and click **Open**
4. Click **Create Project**

RStudio will download the materials and open the project automatically.

- You should also see a file called `check_location.R`.

## Using the H: Drive (University Network Storage)

Your **H: Drive** is personal network storage backed up by IT. It's the safest place for your work on university computers.

### On Campus (Lab PCs)

The H: Drive is automatically available:

1. Open **File Explorer** (Win+E)
2. Look for **(H:)** under "This PC"

### From Home (Personal Laptop)

1. Connect to the **University VPN** first ([VPN Guide](https://www.bath.ac.uk/guides/setting-up-vpn-on-your-device/))
2. Map the network drive:
   - **Windows**: Right-click This PC â†’ Map network drive â†’ `\\myfiles.campus.bath.ac.uk\username`
   - **Mac**: Finder â†’ Go â†’ Connect to Server â†’ `smb://myfiles.campus.bath.ac.uk/username`
